result.markdown:
--- title: "Basic Statistics U2 Concerts" author: "Hans van Leeuwen" --- In this section we look at some basic statistics of the U2 shows and compare this with the statistics listed at . ## Load custom concertData package First we load my custom concertData package where I organized all the functions to analyze the U2 concert data. This R package is available on my GitHub page at: . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} devtools::load_all("../packages/concertData") library(concertData) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # read the following file where the Rosemont duplication was not fixed yet # this is explained further down on this page u2data <- read_concertData_csv('u2data/archive/u2data_all_shows_clean_final_rosemontdup.csv') ``` ::: ## Longest set lists List the shows with the longest set lists, i.e. where U2 played most songs in a concert. The list corresponds to the statistics at . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # longest set lists longest_setlists <- find_longest_setlists(u2data) print(longest_setlists) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` date city country venue Number of songs played 1 2015-12-06 Paris France AccorHotels Arena 27 2 2018-05-02 Tulsa USA BOK Center 27 3 2015-10-18 Cologne Germany Lanxess Arena 27 ``` ::: ::: The info at : ![Longest U2 set lists - source u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_longest_setlists-u2gigscom.png) One of these shows, with 27 songs played, was in Cologne on October 18th, 2015. I was there with my wife, and before the show we had the chance to meet and greet with Adam Clayton, U2's bass player. He signed my copy of the 1991 Achtung Baby album. I have included some pictures of that moment below. ![Meeting Adam Clayton in Cologne - source Hans van Leeuwen - 18 October 2015.](u2hvl/AdamClaytonCologne.JPG){width="208"} ![Meeting Adam Clayton in Cologne - source Hans van Leeuwen - 18 October 2015.](u2hvl/HvLmeetandgreetAdamClayton.JPG){width="246"} ![Meeting Adam Clayton in Cologne - source Hans van Leeuwen - 18 October 2015.](u2hvl/AchtungBaby_signed.JPG){width="162"} ## Shows with most snippets A snippet is a short piece of song (either from another artist or from U2 themselves) played as part of a regular song in the show. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Get shows with most snippets snippet_summary <- find_shows_with_most_snippets(u2data) head(snippet_summary, n=10) # Show top 10 shows ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10 Ã— 5 date city country venue number_snippets_played 1 2015-11-28 Dublin Ireland 3Arena 24 2 2015-11-19 Belfast Northern Ireland The SSE Arena 23 3 2015-10-30 London England The O2 23 4 2015-11-24 Dublin Ireland 3Arena 20 5 2015-11-23 Dublin Ireland 3Arena 20 6 2015-11-03 London England The O2 20 7 2015-05-19 San Jose USA SAP Center at Saâ€¦ 20 8 2015-12-06 Paris France AccorHotels Arena 19 9 2015-11-27 Dublin Ireland 3Arena 19 10 1997-07-31 Mannheim Germany Maimarkt 19 ``` ::: ::: The info at : ![U2 shows with most snippets played - source u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_shows_most_snippets-u2gigscom.png) I noticed a discrepancy in number of snippets for some of these shows when comparing with the statistics at , for example the London show on November 3rd, 2015, where my data calculates the number of snippets played as 20, while the info at states 19. I first checked in my data which song was incorrectly identified as snippet. That turned out to be 'Even Better Than The Real Thing'. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # check london show 2015-11-03 london_show <- subset(u2data, date == '2015-11-03' & snippet == TRUE, select = c("showID", "date","song_title", "snippet")) print(london_show, n = max()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 20 Ã— 4 showID date song_title snippet 1 1957 2015-11-03 Van Morrison's Gloria TRUE 2 1957 2015-11-03 Do You Remember Rock 'n' Roll Radio? TRUE 3 1957 2015-11-03 Hold Me Close TRUE 4 1957 2015-11-03 When Johnny Comes Marching Home TRUE 5 1957 2015-11-03 Psalm 23 TRUE 6 1957 2015-11-03 Love and Peace or Else TRUE 7 1957 2015-11-03 Words TRUE 8 1957 2015-11-03 A Clockwork Orange TRUE 9 1957 2015-11-03 Even Better Than The Real Thing TRUE 10 1957 2015-11-03 Burning Down The House TRUE 11 1957 2015-11-03 Young Americans TRUE 12 1957 2015-11-03 1969 TRUE 13 1957 2015-11-03 Love Me Do TRUE 14 1957 2015-11-03 Ode To Joy TRUE 15 1957 2015-11-03 19 TRUE 16 1957 2015-11-03 California (There Is No End To Love) TRUE 17 1957 2015-11-03 Yellow TRUE 18 1957 2015-11-03 Live Forever TRUE 19 1957 2015-11-03 Mother And Child Reunion TRUE 20 1957 2015-11-03 40 TRUE ``` ::: ::: The issue seems to be in the different HTML coding for one snippet on that page: ![London snippet count - source u2gigs.com - 3 November 2015.](u2gigs/london_snippet_count_u2gigscom.png) If we check the HTML code for the 'Fish Out of Water Mix' we see that it has a 'snippet' tag: ```
  • Even Better Than The Real Thing Fish Out of Water Mix
    • ``` Now compare this to what the HTML looks like normally for snippets at u2gigs.com: ```
  • Mysterious Ways / Burning Down The House (snippet) / Young Americans (snippet)
    • ``` I'm not sure what u2gigs.com intended to do here, and whether this is a snippet or not. It does explain the different numbers seen earlier as my scraping code has counted songs preceding songs with those tags as snippet incorrectly. ## Cities with most shows We used this metric for data curation already, but here is the top 11 (instead of Top 10 so that Amsterdam is displayed ðŸ˜€ ) of cities where U2 played most often. This matches exactly the statistics listed at . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # cities with most shows played top_cities <- find_most_played_cities(u2data, n = 13) print(top_cities) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` city number_of_shows 1 Dublin 202 2 New York 146 3 London 126 4 Las Vegas 54 5 Los Angeles 53 6 Chicago 41 7 Boston 35 8 Toronto 30 9 Paris 29 10 East Rutherford 27 11 Sydney 27 12 Washington 27 13 Amsterdam 23 ``` ::: ::: The info at : ![Cities with most shows played - source u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_top_played_cities-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} ## Venues with most shows Here is the top 10 of venues where U2 played most often. This matches exactly the statistics listed at . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Get top 10 venues with most shows played top_venues <- find_most_played_venues(u2data, n = 10) print(top_venues) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` venue city number_of_shows 1 Sphere Las Vegas 40 2 Madison Square Garden New York 30 3 McGonagle's Dublin 28 4 United Center Chicago 19 5 Entertainment Centre Sydney 14 6 Croke Park Dublin 13 7 Sports Arena Los Angeles 13 8 Staples Center Los Angeles 13 9 Beacon Theatre New York 13 10 Arcadia Ballroom Cork 11 ``` ::: ::: The info at : ![Venues with most shows played - source u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_top_played_venues-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} ## Countries with most shows The top 10 of countries where U2 played most often can be seen below. This matches exactly the statistics listed at . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # countries with most shows played # Get top 10 countries with most shows played top_countries <- find_most_played_countries(u2data, n = 10) print(top_countries) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` country number_of_shows 1 USA 930 2 England 279 3 Ireland 279 4 Canada 80 5 Germany 78 6 Australia 75 7 France 63 8 Netherlands 61 9 Italy 46 10 Scotland 32 ``` ::: ::: The info at : ![Countries with most shows played - source u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_top_played_countries-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} ## Top 10 most played songs Before we look at the top 10, let's see how many different songs U2 has played live. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # number of unique songs played nrow(unique(u2data[,c('song_title')])) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 994 ``` ::: ::: This does not match the info at as there it is stated: > We have 1011 different songs in our database. However, at at a different page () it is stated: > We found 994 different songs in our database. And that number coincides with the number found in my data. The top 10 of songs that U2 played most often can be seen below. This does not match completely with the statistics listed at . There are several songs that have a count that is 1 higher in my data (Pride, Streets, One, Bullet, Still Haven't Found). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # songs most played top_played_songs <- find_most_played_songs(u2data, n = 15) print(top_played_songs) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 Ã— 4 song_title times_played_total times_played_regular times_played_snippet 1 Sunday Bloody Sâ€¦ 1082 935 147 2 Pride (In the Nâ€¦ 1057 1057 0 3 I Will Follow 1053 1053 0 4 Where the Streeâ€¦ 977 975 2 5 With or Withoutâ€¦ 913 910 3 6 One 865 852 13 7 New Year's Day 805 804 1 8 Bullet the Blueâ€¦ 793 793 0 9 I Still Haven'tâ€¦ 697 691 6 10 Beautiful Day 674 673 1 11 Until the End oâ€¦ 648 648 0 12 Mysterious Ways 639 639 0 13 Vertigo 603 586 17 14 Bad 568 561 7 15 Elevation 560 558 2 ``` ::: ::: The info at : ![Most played songs - source u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/U2_shows_top_played_songs-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} I took a closer look at the song Pride to see where the difference of 1 time played is between my data and the data at . I copied all the times the song was played from that page and pasted in Excel. With the code below I obtained the list from my data and compared that side by side in Excel. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Pride - number of times played pride_data <- subset(u2data, song_title == 'Pride (In the Name of Love)', select = c("date","city","tour", "song_title", "showID")) #write.csv(pride_data, "pride_data.csv") ``` ::: I discovered that the issue in my data is at the ZOO TV show on March 31, 1992 in Rosemont: . Pride was played one time at that show but appears in my data as it was played 2 times during that show: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Rosemont show 1992 set list rosemont_data <- subset(u2data, showID == 235, select = c("date", "city", "song_position","song_title","snippet", "encore")) print(rosemont_data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 46 Ã— 6 date city song_position song_title snippet encore 1 1992-03-31 Rosemont 1 Zoo Station FALSE FALSE 2 1992-03-31 Rosemont 2 The Fly FALSE FALSE 3 1992-03-31 Rosemont 3 Even Better Than The Real Tâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 4 1992-03-31 Rosemont 4 Mysterious Ways FALSE FALSE 5 1992-03-31 Rosemont 4 Love To Love You Baby TRUE FALSE 6 1992-03-31 Rosemont 5 One FALSE FALSE 7 1992-03-31 Rosemont 6 Until the End of the World FALSE FALSE 8 1992-03-31 Rosemont 7 Who's Gonna Ride Your Wild â€¦ FALSE FALSE 9 1992-03-31 Rosemont 8 Tryin' to Throw Your Arms Aâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 10 1992-03-31 Rosemont 8 Love And Affection TRUE FALSE # â„¹ 36 more rows ``` ::: ::: With this we can see that there is duplicated data for this show in my data. I went back to my original scraped files and indeed I saw that the duplication happened where the scraping process had been interrupted and later restarted manually. Let's check to what extent there are duplicated rows in my data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # show duplicate rows duplicated_rows <- u2data[duplicated(u2data), ] print(duplicated_rows, n=max()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 24 Ã— 15 showID tour leg date venue city state country song_position snippet 1 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 1 FALSE 2 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 2 FALSE 3 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 3 FALSE 4 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 4 FALSE 5 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 4 TRUE 6 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 5 FALSE 7 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 6 FALSE 8 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 7 FALSE 9 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 8 FALSE 10 235 U2 Zâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 8 TRUE # â„¹ 14 more rows # â„¹ 5 more variables: encore , song_title , show_url , # song_url , song_lyrics ``` ::: ::: Here we see the Rosemont show (show ID 235) again. I manually checked the others: - El Pueblo VencerÃ¡ at show with showID 1056, and also at show with showID 1060 - this turned out to be correct as the snippet was played two times in the same regular song (Mothers of the Disappeared), so it looks like a duplicate row but is correct. - Two Shots of Happy, One Shot of Sad at show with showID 1133 - this also turned out to be correct as the snippet was played two times in the same regular song (Stay), so it looks like a duplicate row but is correct. This means I only have to remove the Rosemont show duplicate rows, as follows: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # retrieve row indices of all duplicated rows which(duplicated(u2data) | duplicated(u2data, fromLast = TRUE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2959 2960 2961 2962 2963 2964 2965 2966 2967 2968 2969 2970 [13] 2971 2972 2973 2974 2975 2976 2977 2978 2979 2980 2981 2982 [25] 2983 2984 2985 2986 2987 2988 2989 2990 2991 2992 2993 2994 [37] 2995 2996 2997 2998 2999 3000 18166 18168 18239 18241 20327 20329 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # the first 21 are the ones that should be deleted # check rows 20, 21 and 22 with indices 2959, 2979 and 2980, respectively u2data[2959,] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 Ã— 15 showID tour leg date venue city state country song_position snippet 1 235 U2 ZOâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 1 FALSE # â„¹ 5 more variables: encore , song_title , show_url , # song_url , song_lyrics ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} u2data[2979,] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 Ã— 15 showID tour leg date venue city state country song_position snippet 1 235 U2 ZOâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 17 FALSE # â„¹ 5 more variables: encore , song_title , show_url , # song_url , song_lyrics ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} u2data[2980,] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 Ã— 15 showID tour leg date venue city state country song_position snippet 1 235 U2 ZOâ€¦ ZOO â€¦ 1992-03-31 Roseâ€¦ Roseâ€¦ Illiâ€¦ USA 1 FALSE # â„¹ 5 more variables: encore , song_title , show_url , # song_url , song_lyrics ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # correct, these two rows correspond to the first one to delete (Zoo Station), the last one to delete (Desire) and the first one to keep (Zoo Station), respectively # thus, we need to remove the rows with indices: # 2959 2960 2961 2962 2963 2964 2965 2966 2967 2968 2969 2970 2971 2972 2973 2974 2975 # 2976 2977 2978 2979 # check number of rows before deletion nrow(u2data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 39674 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # result: 39674 # delete duplicated rows from Rosemont show u2data <- u2data[-(2959:2979),] # check number of rows after deletion nrow(u2data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 39653 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #result: 39653 # difference: 39674 - 39653 print(39674 - 39653) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 21 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # result: 21 #correct # now save corrected data to csv file # commented out because this has already been done #write.csv(u2data, file = "u2data/u2data_all_shows_clean_final.csv", row.names = FALSE) ``` ::: Now that those duplicated rows were removed, let's look at the songs by number of times played again and compare again to the info at . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # read the u2 concertData u2data <- read_concertData_csv('u2data/u2data_all_shows_clean_final.csv') # songs most played top_played_songs <- find_most_played_songs(u2data, n = 15) print(top_played_songs) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 Ã— 4 song_title times_played_total times_played_regular times_played_snippet 1 Sunday Bloody Sâ€¦ 1082 935 147 2 Pride (In the Nâ€¦ 1056 1056 0 3 I Will Follow 1053 1053 0 4 Where the Streeâ€¦ 976 974 2 5 With or Withoutâ€¦ 913 910 3 6 One 864 851 13 7 New Year's Day 805 804 1 8 Bullet the Blueâ€¦ 792 792 0 9 I Still Haven'tâ€¦ 696 690 6 10 Beautiful Day 674 673 1 11 Until the End oâ€¦ 647 647 0 12 Mysterious Ways 638 638 0 13 Vertigo 603 586 17 14 Bad 567 560 7 15 Elevation 560 558 2 ``` ::: ::: Yes, total times the songs were played match now. There is still discrepancies in the times it was played as regular song or snippet. ![Top played songs - u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/U2_shows_top_played_songs-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} Let's check Where The Streets Have No Name. In the u2gigs.com it has a total play count of 976, all regular performances, no snippets. In my data it states 974 regular performances and 2 times as a snippet. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} WTSHNN_regular_play_count <- subset(u2data, song_title == 'Where the Streets Have No Name' & snippet == FALSE, select = c("showID", "date", "city", "song_position","song_title","snippet", "encore")) print(WTSHNN_regular_play_count) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 974 Ã— 7 showID date city song_position song_title snippet encore 1 8 1990-01-05 Rotterdam 5 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 2 9 1990-01-06 Rotterdam 1 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 3 11 1990-01-09 Rotterdam 1 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 4 12 1990-01-10 Rotterdam 6 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 5 29 1998-01-27 Rio de Janeiro 16 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 6 37 1998-01-30 Sao Paulo 15 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 7 42 1998-01-31 Sao Paulo 15 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 8 55 1998-02-05 Buenos Aires 15 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 9 58 1998-02-06 Buenos Aires 15 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE 10 59 1998-02-07 Buenos Aires 16 Where the Streâ€¦ FALSE FALSE # â„¹ 964 more rows ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} WTSHNN_snippet_play_count <- subset(u2data, song_title == 'Where the Streets Have No Name' & snippet == TRUE, select = c("showID", "date", "city", "song_position","song_title","snippet", "encore")) print(WTSHNN_snippet_play_count) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 7 showID date city song_position song_title snippet encore 1 1887 2014-12-01 New York 4 Where the Streets Havâ€¦ TRUE TRUE 2 2108 2017-12-04 New York 4 Where the Streets Havâ€¦ TRUE FALSE ``` ::: ::: In the two shows where my scraping code had counted WTSHNN as a snippet, we see the format difference: ```
  • Where the Streets Have No Name (with Bruce Springsteen)
  • Where the Streets Have No Name partial chords
    • ``` Compared to a more normal coding for regular songs on the u2gigs.com site: ```
  • Where the Streets Have No Name
    • ``` Thus, my scraping code had not identified these two performances of WTSHNN as regular but incorrectly as snippets. As my project was ending I did not follow up to correct my u2data set with these relativelz few errors in the snippet flag. ## Top 10 opening songs Which were the songs U2 played most to open the shows? This can be seen at . ![Top 10 opening songs - u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_top_opening_songs-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} In my data the numbers are like shown below: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Get top 10 opening songs top_10_openers <- find_most_played_opening_songs(u2data, n = 10) print(top_10_openers) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2 song_title times_played 1 Zoo Station 197 2 Gloria 130 3 Elevation 118 4 11 O'Clock Tick Tock 117 5 City of Blinding Lights 116 6 Where the Streets Have No Name 114 7 Mofo 94 8 The Miracle (of Joey Ramone) 85 9 Out of Control 72 10 Sunday Bloody Sunday 71 ``` ::: ::: The numbers did not match the information at . I checked a few songs and observed a few things: First, the opening songs counts listed at seem to be outdated. When you click on one the songs in that list it shows a different number on the song page. For example, Zoo Station has the opening song count of 196 at (see earlier screen shot), but 197 at : ![Zoo Station opening song - u2gigs.com - October 2024.](u2gigs/u2_zoo_station_opening.png){fig-align="left"} Thus, it looks like u2gigs.com needs to refresh the 'Top 25 show opening songs' list at . Second, I observed a few rare cases on the u2gigs.com show pages which were not handled properly by my scraping code, or were not handled properly by u2gigs.com, for example: *Example 1:* Oct 23rd, 2000 set list, : ![Rare setlist format on show page.](u2gigs/u2_2000-10-23_setlist-u2gigscom.png) My code and data did count Elevation as opening song for this 'show' while u2gigs.com did not count it, probably because it was preceded by an interview. The same issue occurred with this show: , and potentially with other shows as I only checked shows that opened with Elevation. u2gigs.com may want to check how they count opening songs in such case. *Example 2* 2001-09-06 set list, . In this case the set list started with a medley, with two songs as one entry. This is different than a regular song plus a snippet. My scraping code could apparently not handle this. ![Rare setlist format on show page.](u2gigs/u2_2001-09-06_setlist-u2gigscom.png){fig-align="left"} I decided not to invest more time in trying to detect and fix these rare issues.
